text:
I made this last week, and I decided after contemplation, that it would be simpler for me to do the entire recipe in an electric skillet, and boy was I right. :)  I browned the patties and then added the soups, etc, and let it all simmer covered for about 15-20 minutes.  It was so easy, and so good, though a bit salty.  Next time, I will only use half of the onion soup mix, and low sodium soup.  I only had one dirty pan to clean, so to me, it was awesome this way. :)

text:
Excellent recipe. My husband loves this meal. The only change I would make is to use 2 cans of cream of mushroom soup instead of the chicken. Both hubby and I didnt care for the recipe when I used the cream of chicken (didnt taste like salisbury steak). Added chopped onion to the mixture for added flavor and use ground SIRLOIN--it's the best. Also, Country Crock now makes mashed potatoes you can buy in the refridgerator isle of the grocery store, they are kind of expensive, but they are sooo good. Makes the meal even easier since you can microwave them! Goes great with the salisbury steak!

text:
This recipe was really easy and very tasty.  The only reason I didn't give it a 5 is because it was a bit salty.  Next time (and there will be a next time) I will use low sodium soup and quarter some potatoes to help with that.  I browned the hamburger patties the night before.  Then the next morning threw it all in the crockpot and was off to work.  Thanks for the post.

text:
This is fantastic salisbury steak.  By far the best I've ever had.  I cut the recipe in half and only made 4 patties.  I omitted cream of chicken soup and substituted a jar of beef gravy.  I also added an entire package of sliced baby portobello mushrooms.  The sauce turned out wonderful but the patties were even better!  Served with egg noodles and green beans.  Thanks!

What a great recipe! I used extra lean ground beef and beefy onion soup mix along with the Italian breadcrumbs and milk to make the patties. For the sauce I used two cans of reduced sodium cream of mushroom soup mixed with the whole packet of au jus and water... came out perfect, not too salty. My two boys and my husband really ate this up! Thanks for a keeper!

country:
None
text:
I have been cooking for 35+ years and this was fabulous!  My husband and kids (who are very picky) cleared their plates and said I could make this "Anytime"!  I made mashed potatoes to go with this dinner - yum!  I used 1/2 of the dry onion/mushroom soup mix so it would not be too salty.  But it is MUCH BETTER with the CREAM OF CHICKEN then the Cream of Mushroom!!!  It may sound strange, but once you add the Dry Au Jus Mix to the Cream of Chicken, it turns it to a beef flavor, not chicken.  Instead of water I also added Chicken Broth.  Beef broth would make it too "beefy".  This gave it a very nice, smooth flavor.  I also added a Jar of Mushrooms (drained).  This is the 3rd time I've made it in a month!!  Very unusual for my household.  I also like it because it is so easy.  Don't over mix your beef mixture, that will make it tough.  If you handle with care, it will not fall apart.  I love it when I find recipes that are wonderful and cooked in slow cooker/crock pot.  =)

text:
I'd give this 5 stars except that I made so many changes. This is definitely a keeper! I read one reviewer that was annoyed at everyone posting their changes to the recipe but I have to say I find those reviews helpful and I'm glad people write down what they changed. I cut it in half since only two of us were eating it so I also only used 1/2 packet of onion soup mix. I added sliced mushrooms and onions. I used 1 can of low sodium cream of mushroom soup instead of the 2 cans of cream of chicken. I didn't have a packet of Au Jus mix so I used a can of low sodium beef broth. I added Worcestershire sauce to the meat. And I added my own secret weapon for gravy - Gravy Master. I love the flavor it adds to gravy! I served it with mashed potatoes and the gravy was So good the mashed potatoes were really only there as a reason to eat more of the gravy. I always thought Salisbury Steak was a lot of work. This recipe made it a snap - even on a work night. Thanks!

text:
We made this last night and it was very good.  I made a few minor changes.  Due to the other reviews regarding the saltiness of the meal, I used half the italian bread crumbs and half plain.  I also used 1-1/2 cup water and added about 1/4 cup red cooking wine.  We didn't think it was too salty...nowhere near too salty, but I could see how others might.  Guess it depends on how much you like salt.  We made it with garlic mashed potatoes and the gravy was great over that as well.  We ate the leftovers today as sandwiches.  Very good.  We will make again.

None
text:
This sounds wonderful, can't wait to try it.  Just a note for those who didn't want to use Cream of Chicken soup...I'm not big on the taste of Cream of Mushroom soup in dishes (seems like when I use Cream of Mushroom or Cream of Celery that's all I can taste).  I've discovered Cream of Onion soup which gives you another layer of onion flavor and the creaminess you're looking for but doesn't dominate with the mushroom or celery flavor.  It also works great when you're making meat free recipies.  Hope that helps someone, it did me.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5317529.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I make this recipe a lot, but I double it to feed my large family.  Because I found it a bit too salty, I reduced the onion soup mix and the au jus mix by half.  It's still good, and brings the saltiness down to an acceptable level for me.  The recipe freezes very well, and if I'm in a rush I don't use the slow cooker, putting the patties & gravy in a baking pan and baking it in the oven at 350* for about an hour.  It's good that way too!
One other thing, I've found it helpful to brown the patties and then remove them from the pan, put them on a layer of paper towels, and let the grease drain for a few minutes before continuing on with the recipe.

i absolutely LOVE this recipe. i have made this about 6 times now. salisbury steak is one of my favorite meals in the world and this always hits the spot. i never make a recipe word for word and this time was no different! i live in OK and never have found an au jus mix so i just get about 4 beef bullion cubes and heat that up with the water, until the bullion has disolved and i also add A LOT of worcestershire sauce (thats the one thing this recipe is lacking!). i also switch the cream of chicken soup to cream of mushroom soup. if i remember i try and add a small can of mushrooms. this time i added 1/2 of an onion and it was great.  this serves 8? man i could eat this whole meal by myself!! ha

text:
Thanks for a creative way to make great salisbury steak! I'm a "temporary" at-home dad, so I felt obligated to make some manly changes of my own: I used frozen hamburger patties (don't judge me), sub'd one can of cream of mushroom with the cream of chicken, and used a packet of beef stew seasoning because I didn't have au jus mix. Not even sure if it's still considered salisbury steak, but it was GREAT...green beans and mac'n'cheese rounded out the meal. If it came out too greasy for anyone, blame it on their choice of fatty ground beef--it's NOT the recipe's fault, sheesh...

This was soooo great! Used the recipe as a model and took some others advice. Here is what made my daughter who doesn't eat beef unless it's in tomato sauce, eat 2 of these burgers!!!! I only used a little of the onion soup and just the powder and put in half a fresh onion finely chopped. Omitted the flour, because i forgot! and used cream of mushroom.Browned the meat on the stovetop and covered with gravy covered the pan and threw it in the oven for about 90 mins on 325*. So stinking good!! My husband said "i didn't know salisbury steak could be made thought it was just a frozen dinner"! HAHA! Thanks for the great base recipe!!! yum!!!

text:
This recipe is our "go-to" for busy days. I've also used cream of celery, cream of asparagus, and cream of mushroom soup, in different combinations, all very tasty. To deal with the draining of fat from the ground beef, I cut up some potatotes and place on bottom of the slow cooker, then put the patties in a pyramid on top -- no sitting in a puddle of grease!

This same recipe can be made in one hour in the oven. I place the patties in a large cake pan, pour the soup mix (without the onion soup) on top, add parsley, onions....surround it with sliced potatoes and bake....the burger bakes in the oven. No need to brown it.

text:
I thought the gravy was WAY too salty, half a packet of the dry au jus mix would help cut back on the salt.  The fat from the beef was difficult to separate from the gravy so I don't think I'll do this recipe in the slow cooker, it just isn't necessary and doesn't work out too well.  I also didn't like the looks of the dry onions in the beef, I will use real onion next time with some spices in place of the dry onion soup mix.**I made this again and omitted the au jus mix completely, used a leaner meat and pounded the dry onion soup mix so the bits of onion would be smaller and it was perfect!

text:
this was my first time to make salisbury steak and i was very impressed with how easy it was. i read other reviews and tips first, and since i didn't have all the exact ingredients, make a few substitutions and also cooked it on the stovetop rather than in the slow cooker and it still turned out great! i cut the recipe in half, using only half the onion soup packet. i didn't have the au jus or the cream soup, so instead i used a can of mushroom gravy and a dry packet of brown gravy (reduced sodium). since i forgot to half it and added the full packet of gravy mix i went ahead and added the full amount of water- so i had extra sauce which is never a bad thing! I also added fresh sliced mushrooms after browning the meat, when i added the gravies. Mine didn't turn out too salty the way i made it. thank you for such a versatile and delicious recipe :) it will be a new staple in our house!

text:
3.5 stars.  According to my boyfriend, though he said this recipe was good, this recipe would also have potential to taste more like Salisbury steak if a few modifications were made.

I followed the recipe exactly as instructed.  As the steaks were being cooked in the Crockpot, I read a few reviews and later agreed that the sauce/gravy would taste better if a cream of mushroom was used instead of condensed chicken soup.  To offset the saltiness, I added 1 chopped onion to the gravy mixture.  In the future, with cream of mushroom soup being used, I would add fresh mushrooms to the Crockpot mix as well.

I served mine with roasted bell peppers and mash potatoes.  The gravy goes very well with the mash potatoes too!

text:
The first time I made this recipe my family found it too salty even though I used Healthy Request Cream of Chicken Soup which is less salty. I think the saltiness came from the dry mixes so I cut out the onion soup mix and added sliced vidalia onion and Healthy Choice Cream of Mushroom Soup for an onion flavor and 1/2 can of low sodium MSG free beef broth for the beef flavor. I still added the milk and this turned out delicious. I have a problem with MSG so those are better choices for me. I would highly reccommend this recipe with those changes for someone with migraine headaches that needs to avoid MSG. I will make this over and over. It is good with mashed potatoes and egg noodles. For those on a low cholesterol diet it can be served over "NO YOLKS" egg noodles and the Salisbury Steak could probably be made with ground turkey, however I have never tried it. I should pass this on to my mother-in-law because she makes everything with ground turkey since my father-in-law's heart attack.

text:
Just like TrishDish, I also used an electric skillet. I think 4 or 5 hours in the slow cooker would definitely dry out the lean ground beef.  Also using low sodium soup is the only way to go.  I have gotten into the habit of using garlic powder, onion powder and/or garlic salt.  Campbell's Soup up here in Canada still makes 25% less sodium soups, but they still contain a rather high sodium content.  Instead of chicken soup, I used Knorr OXO Chicken bouillon which is also available in low sodium.  About 560ml which is just over 2 cups of water with the bouillon sachets and adding garlic powder, and onion powder along with a couple of garlic cloves.  Used some Canada Corn Starch to thicken it, and it is fantastic. I'm glad to hear that my American friends are using lower sodium  and becoming healthier.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I fixed this recipe lastnight after seeing it on pinterest. I read the other reviews before I fixed it. I only used a half of a pack of the onion soup mix. I also used the low sodium soup and I added the beef broth to my mixture. I also used cream of mushroom soup instead of the chicken. Something just seems kind of odd about having chunks of chicken in a salisbury steak. Also, I sauteed some onions in a skillet and added those to the crockpot as well. One more thing I did, I did't fry up the patties in flour, my husband said he didn't want them 'crunchy' so I just fixed them like I would a hamburger and cooked them fully before putting them in the crockpot. I'll definately be making this recipe again!! And thanks to all the ones who had previously put a review up about the recipe so I would know to make some changes as well!

I used low salt onion and chicken soup and instant gravy powder instead of the packet of dry au jus. This is Definitely going to be a regular winter meal!!

I have been making this for a couple years now and am just now reviewing.  This is a great recipe!  However, over the years I have found I prefer cream of mushroom soup over the cream of chicken.  I also concur with several other reviewers that this recipe is salty.  By replacing ingredients with the low sodium counterparts, it eliminates the problem without sacrificing taste.  Enjoy!

text:
This is an excellent crock pot recipe. I would rate it up there with pot roast and beef stew as one of the best recipes for using beef in the slow cooker. You really don’t need to change it to get good results, but I did make two minor tweaks: I used 2 cans of lower sodium cream of mushroom soup with roasted garlic, and I added a package of fresh sliced mushrooms. I thought the mushrooms really added a lot to the recipe. Was fantastic served over garlic mashed potatoes!

text:
I had to adapt this for food allergy reasons and to reduce the sodium and fat.  I made homemade cream of mushroom soup with no sodium added beef broth.  I used skim milk to reduce the fat.  I used (1) no sodium added bouillon packet and added no sodium added broth instead of water.  I browned the patties and baked them (covered) in the oven for 350 F for one hour.  Absolutely delicious!  DH wants this for his birthday dinner.

Loved this recipe.  Hubby said it was a "keeper". As others suggested, I used both cream of chicken soup and mushroom soup.  I added a teaspoon of chopped garlic to the soup mixture and because I like my beef gravy dark, I added a few shakes of kitchen bouquet too.  In addition to the onion soup mix, I added a chopped onion to the meat patties.  I like getting a nice bite of onion in my salisbury steak.  There are only 2 of us, so the first night we had mashed potatoes.  Served it with rice the second night.  Yummy both ways.

This was great!!  I took some of the tips in the reviews.  First, I increased the recipe by half because I cook for teenage boys.   I used beefy onion soup mix in the meat, only 1 packet even though I used 3 lbs of meat.  I also used 2 cans of cream of mushroom, 1 can of golden mushroom, but only the 1 packet of au jus. text:
This was VERY good!  I only had 1 lb. ground beef so I halved the meat mixture ingredients but kept the sauce the same amount as I used it for a gravy.  My original thought was that the meat patties would fall apart in the slow cooker, but they held up VERY well, and were very firm at the end of the cooking process.  I browned them on our grill pan for nice taste and nice grill marks.  For the gravy, I couldn't imagine cooking hamburger in cream of chicken soup so I used 1 can brown gravy and 1 can cream of mushroom.  Very yummy, although I could not taste the au jus packet.  I may leave it out next time as I didn't really find it necessary.  Thanks fr a great base recipe, I will make these again.

text:
I really enjoyed this recipe.  It was simple and easy to make.  The only thing I changed was to cook the beef patties first (because of comments about the grease) and then stack them in the slow cooker as instructed.  My extremely picky 9 year old grandson ate 1 1/2 servings.  Served with mashed potatoes and green beans!  Will make this again!  Thanks for the recipe.  Oh, also used 1 can cream of chicken soup and 1 can of cream of celery soup because that's all I happened to have on hand.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was a great main dish! I did use the cream of chicken soup instead of cream of mushroom like everyone else is suggesting, because no one in my family cares for mushroom. I kept all other ingredients in the recipe the same, aside from adding a few splashes of Worcestershire sauce to the meat mixture. I also decided to cook this in a large deep skillet instead of the slow cooker, and once the meat was browned, I poured the sauce in, turned the heat down to a simmer, and covered it to cook for 15 minutes, flipping the patties once and stirring the sauce a few times. Went great with a side of mashed potatoes and mixed vegetables. Next time I will make this the same way, but use fresh minced onion instead of the soup mix. It was just too salty for my taste. The cream of chicken and au jus does make a delicious sauce though.

text:
The gravy was very, very salty.  My best guess is the Lawry's Au Jus mix I used. I admit, I did not look to see how much was in the packet - just threw the whole thing in. 

Perhaps next time I will cut this in 1/2, or perhaps skip it and substitute low sodium beef broth for the water & Au Jus packet.  

I did like the way the beef itself turned out!  I served it on a thick slice of toasted French bread.  I think next time I will saute some onions & mushrooms to go with it.

this had quickly become my most requested meal by the family. It's delicious! Really no modifications here. Just substitute cream of mushroom for the cream of chicken (this seems like a no brainier to me - and I don't even like mushroom!) and I usually slice up an onion and place a whole slice on the top of each patty in the slow cooker. Gets super tender and tasty! Serve with mashed potatoes and enjoy!

text:
Have made this recipe so many times I now turn it into two meals, night one serve over mashed  potatoes, night two I reserve some of the sauce mixture instead of adding it all to the crockpot, cut up the leftover steak patties and toss everything with cooked egg noodles. I love making " 2 for 1 " meals to save time. I usually make meal two while I am cleaning up from meal one so it is done and out of the way, then just reheat in the oven the next night and serve with a vegetable.  This recipe is on the salty side so just have to tweak it a bit.

This was amazing.  I scaled this down to half and did what everyone else suggested and used cream of mushroom.  I also added baby portobello mushrooms and worcestershire sauce. I cooked the meat with flour first as suggested then cooked on high for 3 hours.  The meat was not dry,  very moist and not salty at all.  For those who felt the meat broke apart, I suggest you break off a small piece of meat and fry it first then you can see how it holds up.

text:
This is a wonderful recipe.  I tweaked this one a bit to suit our preferences by doing the following:  I substituted cream of mushroom soup for the cream of chicken (I detest those odd little pink chicken bits!), added a can of sliced mushrooms and one half of a large yellow onion, thinly sliced, right at the beginning of cooking, and threw in a few drops of Kitchen Bouquet to darken the gravy.  I also cooked it an hour longer than directed in the recipe.  We found the meat extremely tender, the gravy absolutely delicious---we didn't find it too salty at all.  I will make this again and again.  Thanks for sharing, Tesslynn.

Display Name:
Rachael Showmaker

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is your grandma's Salisbury steak recipe,  not that freezer section . My bf LOVES this recipe. He always comes home from work saying how all his co workers loved how it smelled and asks what he has. I use all the ingredients as stated, expect I buy family packs of gr. Beef and just spilt it in two, so I probably use about 3 lbs of meat instead of two which I think lessens the salty taste, but it can be salty if you don't use that much meat. My gravy always turns out a little runny and I have to play with it to thicken it up some. I drain the patties before adding to the slow cooker. This could be done in just a pan, your basically frying burgers then letting it soak in the slow cooker for 5 hours. It doesn't really need to go into one, but I'm a stay at home wife for now so I can start dinner and then clean or whatever and come back hours later, make a few sides and dinners done. It takes me about an hour to prep and cook everything, but again, I'm not in a rush so after I make the patties I throw them in the fridge for 20 mins like you would if bbqing. I serve with brussel sprouts or broccoli, a salad or corn, and potatoes or r biscuits.  You kinda need the potatoes or biscuits to soak up the awesome gravy. And I like the color the other veggies gives to the plate. 

I think adding mushrooms to this would be awesome. Enjoy! This is one recipe you won't regret making. I've shared with friends and everyone LOVES it. Easy, especially if you don't add the slow cooker.

text:
My mom use to make something like this with just hamburgers so it took me back. To make it healthier I used about 1/3 cup oatmeal instead of bread crumbs & through in some oregano, garlic, basil, black pepper, & red pepper flakes along w/ an egg & the milk.  Also, I added about 1/4 to 1/3 cup shredded onion instead of the onion soup mix.  I cooked it all in an electric skillet like someone else suggested. The meat was good but the gravy was a bit too salty even though I used reduced sodium cream of chicken. The next time I make I'm not going to put the whole packet of beef mix in the soup & see how that comes out.  Everyone seemed to like it.

text:
This was easy to make and delicious! My picky daughter didn't mind leftovers the next night, and that's saying something. If it was more than just the two of us, there probably wouldn't have been leftovers. I followed others' advice and used cream of mushroom soup instead of cream of chicken. When making the gravy, be sure to stir the au jus mix into the soup until it's thoroughly mixed and creamy. When it's ready to eat, you won't mind that extra moment of stirring. I'll definitely make this again!

text:
Absolutely deliciouss!!  Used one cream of mushroom and one cream of mushroom and chicken.  The gravy has a slightly processed taste will work on it.  Maybe deleting the dry au jus mix and just using some cornstarch and beef boullion seasoning instead.  But I'd still make it again using the au jus mix if that didn't work out.  My family loved this.  UPDATE:  made again and left out the dry au jus mix.  Used 1 can of cream of mushroom & chicken and 1 can of cream of mushroom.  Added like 2 cups beef broth in place of water with 2 beef bouillon cubes (mashed with a meat mallet in a small plastic bag).  When it was done I removed the meat and added a little cornstarch mixed with water to thicken the gravy.  It was really tasty without a processed taste.  I also added 2 drained cans of mushroom slices to the gravy.  Put the steak patties back in the gravy and served over mashed potatoes.  Wonderful recipe.  My whole family loves this meal.

Display Name:
MamaStotch

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614256.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Fabulous recipe, but I agree with the other reviewers - very salty!  I made a few changes to help with that...used onion flakes instead of onion soup mix, low-sodium cream of mushroom soup instead of cream of chicken, and I whipped this all up in my electric skillet rather than the slow cooker to speed up cooking time on my busy weeknight.  Once the patties were browned in the skillet I added in the cream of mushroom, au jus, and water and let it all simmer for about 20 minutes with the lid on, and it was terrific.  Served with egg noodles, although next time I'll be serving it with mashed potatoes to soak up that gravy goodness!

text:
I have to give this a low rating becuase the person who added it, didn't give an importnat detail. You have to skim the fat/grease off, to have any decent gravy, even then it's not good.

The Salisbury Steak turns out great, but the gravy is worthless. Because of the fact that you "quickly brown" the steaks, the fat/grease cooks off into the gravy. You have to have a skimmer, to remove the fat/grease. I would recommned cooking the steak, but fixing gravy on the stove.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I thought this was pretty good, and very easy to make.  It didn't taste like TV dinner salisbury steaks, which is what I was craving (I don't care who you are...those are good!), but they were still very tasty.  They were definitely salty, though...and I LOVE salty food!  I second all the reviews saying to use low-sodium soups.  I also found that my 2 tablespoons of oil was pretty much absorbed by the first two steaks, so I used non-stick spray for the rest, and it worked quite well!  I think I'll skip the oil altogether in the future and just use the spray.  (By the way, I didn't have time to wait 4 or 5 hours, so after browning the steaks in a skillet, I put everything in a 9x13-inch pan and baked in a 350 degree oven for 30 minutes.)

I did make some changes, but all the basics came from here - thanks so much! Used cream of mushroom soup, and subbed 1/4 cup of red wine for some of the water. Added a can of drained mushrooms, and used chicken gravy mix instead. Prepped slow cooker with quick 'spray' of oil; after frying patties, I covered them with thinly sliced onion, and then poured liquids on top. Truly wonderful flavour, with mashed potatoes & french bread. Got kiss from hubby for this one!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have made this many times now without the crock and with slight variation to Tesslynn's recipe.  It has become a regular on our family menu and gets requested by both my husband and kids.  
Recipe changes - We use 2 lbs. of ground turkey instead of beef,  substitute one of the cans of condensed cream of chicken soup with condensed cream of mushroom soup, and changed liquids to 1/2 cup of water and 1/2 cup of skim milk.
Cooking changes - I moved recently and chucked out the old crock pot so I have an alternative that's pretty easy.  Oven at 350.  Mix ingredients, make patties, and dredge in flour.  Then I place them on a cookie sheet covered with foil and sprayed with cooking spray (easy clean-up).  Cook at 350 for 45 minutes, turning after the first 30 minutes.  In stock pot, mix together the cream of mushroom soup, au jus mix, and water/milk. Heat till warm.  Place patties in the soup and mix.  Cook on Low for 15 minutes.
We have it with rice or mashed potatoes and a good veg.

text:
Main reason for only 3 stars - the gravy was way to salty!  Patties are workable as is, but I do recommend making sure they're not made to thick. I did alter the recipe using 3 1/2 lbs of meat and mine ended up shrinking and puffing up to about a inch in thickness, even though they were a 1/2 inch when I started.  The whole time while eating I was thinking about how much better they would be if not so thick (my doing though) and if the gravy wasn't so darn salty! Even though I will definitely have to tweak this recipe to get it right, it is still worth trying again.  There's potential, but as is sorry, no.

text:
Wonderfully delicious!  I was excited to make this after reading the reviews, but I didn't have all the ingredients.  So after studying the reviews, I tried one of the suggestions that worked wonderfully.  I used low-sodium Cream of Mushroom soup instead of Cream of Chicken soup and added 2 tsp Worcestershire Sauce, 1 tsp Gravy Master and 1 cup beef broth (I wanted extra for gravy) as a substitute for Au Jus mix.  I let it simmer in a crock pot for 5 hours and the gravy was incredible with garlic mashed potatoes and mixed veggies.  I also noticed a pressure cooker recipe that cooks the meat and gravy for 15min on high pressure with a 10 min natural release that I'm looking forward to trying. I'm confident this will be served many more times to come!

This recipe is amazing! It was so easy to make and absolutely delicious. The only thing I added was sautéed mushrooms into the crockpot to cook with the meat. The one thing I will change next time is that making it into 8 patties made them very thick like burgers. So next time I will make them smaller and come out with 12.

This turned out superb.  Hubby loved it and wants me to make it again, with my minor changes.  I had about 1/2 small carton of mushrooms (mixed varieties) which I added to the pot along with a can of cream of mushroom soup - I wanted lots of sauce.  A tad more liquid was added to make up for the added 2nd can of soup.  I think the addition of the soup, mushrooms, and water help with the saltiness of the Au jus mix.  This is a definite keeper.

text:
This was flavorful and delicious. I did make a few changes to suit my tastes though.

*Plain bread crumbs instead of seasoned.
*Cream of mushroom instead of chicken. 
*Brown gravy mix, in place of the au jus.
*Fresh sliced mushrooms.

I will note that I cut the recipe in half, since it's just my Husband and I- and it was still a lot of food. It made two decent sized patties each, and neither of us could start on the second one. They are very filling. Some may want to consider cutting this down more to avoid wasting food.

text:
I LOVED this dish!  You know how reviews always start with "I didn't change a thing" and then the next word is "except"?  I. DIDN'T. CHANGE. A. THING.  :)  This recipe is absolutely wonderful exactly as it's written out here.  Clear directions, easy to follow, and delicious!  Other reviewers have cautioned about the salty flavor.  I will say this:  I'm from the South, where we use salt liberally, so I found it PERFECT.  It certainly did not need any more salt added, but I thought it was perfect the way it was.  If you have a bit of a lower tolerance for salt, then you might want to do as others have suggested and halve the onion mix to help with that.  I think this is a delicious, savory, rich recipe, and I will absolutely make it again!  Thank you for posting this one!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was the most wonderful Salisbury steak ever. My husband who is not a big Salisbury steak lover, absolutely loved this recipe. If you use the exact pounds of ground beef, it is not too salty. I thought it was perfect and rounded out the meal with garlic mashed potatoes and green beans. DELISH!!!!!! I love the cream of chicken with the packet of au jus. The gravy had the perfect beefy flavor. I added the entire packet of lipton onion soup mix, with some fine cut chopped onions to the beef mixture. I did use 1lb of ground chuck and 1lb of ground sirloin. If you cannot find ground sirloin, use 93% lean ground beef. I also added more water to my soup mix. I think that helped with the saltiness. I cut up some fresh onions and let it cook. Perfect Salisbury steak. Just add more water to your soup mix and it will not be too salty and absolutely perfect.

text:
One word.  Yum.   OK more than one word--easy as heck to make, and I do agree with others that it is a bit on the salty side, so you might want to heed the advise of using lower sodium cream of chicken soup or lower sodium au jus, but this is a wonderful recipe and a perfect example of why I use allrecipes.com like a cooking Bible (no, I don't work for them :)).  No, the recipe didn't make ground beef taste like prime rib, it just made it taste like good comfort food.  You might want to double the gravy for the mashed potatoes which invariably must be served with it.  Thanks Tess for sharing

text:
I'll definitely make this again!  I did have to tweak it though because I didn't have all the ingredients on hand. I had to use cream of mushroom soup instead of cream of chicken. I had to make my own Onion Soup Mix by using a recipe I found on here.  It called for 2 tbsp of beef bullion but I only had cubes.  I found that 1 cube was equivalent to 1 tsp but I thought 6 tsp was way too much so I only used 4 cubes.  I also didn't have dried onion so I just used raw onion.  I also had to substitute a packet of Au Jus with a packet of brown gravy mix and I had some mushrooms that needed to be used so I threw those in too.  It was delicious!  We served it over mashed potatoes.  Yum!

text:
This is one of my "go to" recipes for an easy weeknight meal.  My kids and husband love it.  I have used it as a slow cooker recipe and an oven recipe.  I know that I lose some big flavor by skipping the browning step, but less dirty dishes and less time mean a lot in my household (we have 5 kids, 5 years old and under).  This recipe has such big flavors we don't miss out. Using the oven method I simply assemble the patties and arrange them in a baking dish, cover with sauce and bake for one hour on 375.  Both ways are amazing.

text:
This was amazing!! I had every intention of cooking it in the slow cooker. That's why I picked it to try. But, I decided to fix it with only about 3 hours. So, I followed the directions for the meat, browned them then put them in a single layer in a casserole dish. For the gravy I added 1 tbsp Worcestershire sauce and 1 tsp dry mustard and poured it over the steaks. I baked it on 350 for a little over an hour. My whole family loved it. This has been one of my sons favorite dishes and he couldn't stop talking about it. The gravy was perfect. The steaks were perfect. So, we will definitely fix this again.

text:
Our whole family loved this dish.  I think the key is to use a very low fat beef as it cooks the majority of the time in the crock pot.  After browning the patties, I used the paper towel method to "squeeze" out some of the grease.  It was a hit with my family! I might try making it 1/2 with ground turkey or chicken.  I do agree that less onion soup mix is needed.  I bet the other powdered mix has a high sodium content.

text:
Simple to make, filling, tasty.  That's a pretty good combination!  I was too lazy to flour and brown the patties so I just made them up and layered them in the slow cooker.  Added an egg to the patty mix and omitted the milk.  Threw some black pepper and some minced garlic into the sauce.  My husband loved it served over buttered noodles with green beans.  Would be really good with crushed / mashed potatoes, too.  Thanks for this good recipe!!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Wonderful, we loved it. I'm always looking to save time, and this is certainly a time saver, and a GREAT idea. I think though that the grease issue may turn some people off -- it should be stressed... you must use VERY LEAN meat, or, as i do, ground turkey.  I mix a couple of spoonfuls of the onion soup mix in my ground turkey, I add onion and sometimes peppers.  I don't use cream of chicken, I try to stick with a beef flavor all around.. and I always add mushrooms to the sauce.. try it with a can of golden mushroom, whats' left of the onion soup mix and a bit of brown gravy mix. ... and dont forget to taste the sauce, if its too salty thin it out and then thicken with cornstarch, or do as I do, use lo or no salt options :) - This is a wonderful and delicious dish, but do think about you and your familys' tastes and adjust accordingly :) Thanks for a wonderful recipe Tesslynn :) We love it here!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Great way to cook hamburger steaks.  Because we did not have access to a packet of gravy mix, we made our own: twist of fresh grated pepper, 1/2 cube vege bouillon, 1 cube beef bouillon, onion and garlic powder (1/4 tsp each), 2 tablespoon flour, 1/2 teaspoon cornstarch, 1 tablespoon catsup.  Will remember next time to make the hamburger steaks SMALLER, as they did not shrink much during cooking and were quite fat.  Good gravy - used fat free half and half in place of water.  Brown the hamburgers, added the soup and gravy and cream; covered and cooked at 180 degrees for 4 hours in the oven.  Thanks for sharing!

text:
I was a little leery when reading the ingredients but I trusted the reviews.  I did everything as it called for, incl using the cream of chicken.  I do NOT enjoy mushrooms so I wasn't even tempted to sub the cream of mushroom soup. However, it was very good.  You would've never known that cream of chicken was used in this recipe. It was creamy, smooth, still beefy and good.  It all cooks together wonderfully. I did add 1/2 of a sweet onion in the gravy(this was the only change I made)... it didn't hurt it but honestly, it didn't need it. The onion soup mix in the meat is enough and cooks in w/ the the gravy.  I added pepper while browning the patties and a good dose of it in the gravy to suit my taste.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674169.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Easy to make and was well -received by my family.  I found the salt and strong flavor from the soup mix to be somewhat overwhelming for my individual taste- if you double the recipe, this is not an issue.  Perhaps, for those who dislike so much sodium flavor, try cutting back in the soup mix amount or find a low-sodium alternative.  I also added freshly-chopped onions, which enhanced the texture and subtle flavor.  While I personally do not care for the flour and frying, which makes the meat feel dense and somewhat "pasty" to me, my family devoured all of this and remarked over and over about how much they loved it.  All in all a decent recipe for a meal that is very filling and relatively easy to make, frying excluded.

I took into account all of the other reviews before I made this recipe and used a couple of other peoples revisions.  My husband said "Don't ever lose this recipe," because this is the best Salisbury Steak he has ever had!  I supplemented the Onion Soup w/ Beefy Onion Soup packet.   I supplemented one can of Cream of Chicken Soup w/ Cream of Mushroom Soup.  I added one tbsp. of minced garlic in olive oil to the gravy and used 1/4 cup of merlot and 1/2 cup of beef broth instead of the water!  I also added sliced Portabello Mushrooms in the last thirty minutes of cook time!  This was EXCELLENT!!!!!  I'll be making this recipe the rest of my life!

text:
This was really easy and very tasty.  I never quite follow a recipe (even my own) and this one is very versatile.  Herbs are an easy addition to the meat mixture to change it up a a bit.  I also added cayenne pepper because we seem to love it in so many things.  Also I subbed mushroom gravy mix for the au jus as that is what I had on hand.  Quick tip...if you are trying to watch carbs as we do...omit the flour and milk and just add a couple of eggs.  Also I freeze leftover whole wheat buns and bread and just pop them in the toaster after defrosting to make homemade whole grain bread crumbs.  Cheap and easy!

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
5 star with several reviewers input - after reading a lot of reviewers say too salty and why use cr. of chx with beef? Here's how to turn this 4 star into 5 stars:  (1) use 1/2 pkt dry onion soup mix (I had Lipton mushroom and onion soup mix and it was great); (2) I used Pacific's Portabello ready to serve cream of mushroom soup in a 32 oz. box and I added the whole thing and omitted the water; (3) added 1 cup of dehydrated mushrooms that gave it a rich flavor; (4) added 2 cloves minced garlic to meatballs (5) omitted bread crumbs - don't need it to stay together and don't need extra salt or carbs.  I also saved the step and didn't brown my meat, eliminating the flour and oil.  Served with mashed potatoes and the gravy and fresh green beans with mushrooms from this site.  Awesome meal and great to see my NC mtn hubby so satisfied with a heathly meal.

text:
Oh this is money. My family loved it so much. I made a few changes and I think I'm gonna do a little more but why not have fun with your food? The onion soup mix was the onion/mushroom. I used plain bread crumbs and seasoned it with onion powder, garlic powder, thyme, parsley, sage, salt, and pepper. I used sliced mushrooms, cream of mushroom soup, and beef broth. I didn't put this in my slow cooker I had ran out of time so I pan fried the patties made the gravy and let it stew in the pan for bout an hour. The gravy was perfect and the patties were incredibly moist. What I would do different is put the au ju mix back in the recipe (I shied away reading that this meal was salty) and add sliced onions. I think this recipe should taste more beefy and savory. Amazing meal!

text:
I made the patties exactyly like the recipe said, removed them from my electric skillet then sauted some onion garlic and mushrooms. I took some beef boulion and mixed it with hot water to disolve, mixed some cream of mushroom soup with it, poured 1/2 in tthe skillet with the mushrooms and onion mixed it up placed the patties on top of that and poured the rest of the "gravy" over the patties. Let it simmer for about 30 minutes (enough time to make mashed potatoes) and they loved it!

This was GREAT!  My husband and two young children loved it!  I ran out of time to do it in the crock pot, so after I browned the patties in a skillet, I drained the excess oil, returned the patties to the skillet, poured the mixed sauce ingredients over them and simmered, covered, for about 30 minutes, or until no longer pink.  Served over mashed potatoes.  This would be a great week night recipe too!

text:
Awesome recipe, I did take some reviewers advice and use cream of mushroom soup since I do like it much better.  I also made this a second time, and that time I cooked a package of sliced mushrooms in butter and bits of the hamburger grease and spooned them on top of the patties, that I had layered in a casserole dish.  Then I added a package of brown gravy mix to the cream of mushroom soup sauce to darken and beef it up a bit, covered and cooked it for little over an hour at 350.  My family really liked the changes, and to me it was much easier than using the crock pot.  But when I'm working overtime I could sure see putting it back in the crock pot.  This will sure be a regular on my table. TY for this recipe!

text:
I made this for a house full of family.  All the plates were cleaned and the kids even ate it.  The reason it got 4 stars, though, is I found it way too salty.  Most in my family didn't agree, but I am sensitive to the salt.   I increased the meat to 3# of meat, but still used just one packet of the onion soup mix - so I thought this would help decrease the salty taste.  I would have enjoyed chopping fresh onions instead of the onion soup mix, I think.  Or, next time I will try the potatoes that other viewers mentioned.   I did increase the sauce, since I used 3# of meat.  I had to mix both cr. of chicken and cr. of mushroom - since that was what was in the cupboard.  I also added a small can of mushrooms and more water.  The sauce was yummy.

Delicious! Great base recipe... Used pre-made chopped sirloin patties (just cause I had them)...dredged in flour with granulated garlic, pepper and mrs dash. text:
I gave this recipe 4 stars because the first time I made it I followed the recipe exactly and it was too salty and I wasn't fond of the cream of chicken flavor.  The second time I made it, it was fantastic and now my favorite dinner.  To make this a 5 star recipe I used a packet of brown gravy mix instead of au jus and substituted low sodium beef broth for the water, I also used low sodium cream of mushroom soup instead of cream of chicken.  I used 4% fat beef and it held together very well, you could even use 7% fat.  This was soo incredibly good the second time around with the alterations made.

This is one of my favorite new recipes!!!  I have made it twice, and stuck a bit more to the recipe the second time which worked out better. We loved this recipe.  I used one lb. of hamb. and browned it in a hot skillet.  Then I drained off the grease.  I made my own gravy from the drippings. ( No soup and no au jus packet).  I used one TB. of dry onion soup mix.  It was delicious and I will make it again.  It was not too salty.  I love having things ready in the slow cooker!

text:
This is one of my husband's favorite recipes! (Or it was, before he started eating healthier!) Everyone in my family likes it. It is definitely very salty, but we like it that way. I add pepper to the ground beef mixture. I have used substitutes with good results, like cream of mushroom soup instead of chicken, or a can of beef consumme instead of the au jus mix & water. Use the leanest meat you can afford! I usually use 85/15, and find it is easy to spoon most of the grease off the top with a spoon. I always serve it with mashed potatoes.

text:
Delicious!  I halved the recipe and made 5 patties.  Only real changes I made were to used canned beef gravy instead of the cream of chicken soup and I added a 1/4 cup more water than the halved recipe called for.  Very tasty - way better than frozen - and the extra gravy was great on instant mashed potatoes.  Also served with veggies.  Easy, tasty dinner idea - and great comfort food!!

UPDATE: Made again using condensed French Onion soup - again, very good, although the sauce was thinner.

I was worried that this would end up tasting like hamburger, but it actually had quite a decent steak-y taste. The 2 things that let it down were - 1. the sauce was SO salty. 2. Oh, I don't have a slow cooker, so I baked it, covered, in the oven for an hour.

I used a whole can as well as we used an instant pot and needed the liquid for pressure and only half cup of water instead. in the instant pot we did it for 30 minutes and a 10 minute natural release and it turned out great still very juicy and had great flavor.

I only needed to make a serving for 4, so I used 1 lb ground beef and about half of all the ingredients, except I did use the entire au jus mix for the gravy. This was loved by all my family including my picky 1 year old.  I also started it late so I had the dish in the crock pot for an hour and a half on high, then turned it down to low. It was ready in about 2 1/2-3 hours

text:
Very good, but I took the suggestion to just cook it on the stove top.  I only made 6 servings, so I used only 1 can of cream of mushroom soup, a beef boullion cube, gravy mix (I didn't have an aujus packet) and about 3 cups of water and let the gravy and hamburger patties simmer together.  I under salted the mashed potatoes that I served them with and the dish wasn't too salty.  I think the trick to the saltiness is the water content (or lack thereof).

So simple but so delicious. The steaks were fall-apart tender and so full of comforting homemade flavor. My husband loved it and wants it added to our favorites. My only issue is that, as some other reviewers noted, it is rather salty even though I scaled back a bit on the dry soup mix and au jus mix. Next time I'll use reduced-sodium cream of chicken soup and hop that helps. Otherwise this was a winner - and a keeper.

text:
Delicious. I hadn’t had Salisbury steak since high school — and that was a long time ago.  This recipe scratched an itch that I didn’t realize I had. 

I changed a couple things. I swapped out one can of cream of chicken for a can of cream of mushroom. I also processed the soup mix into a finer mixture in the food processor because I worried the large slivers of dehydrated onion would make for a less cohesive patty. 

I served it with mashed potatoes and steamed green beans. Smiles all around the table!

Not too salty for us, and we usually omit or reduce salt on everything we cook. Thanks for this great recipe!

text:
I've made this numerous times because my husband just loves it and it's so easy for the delicious results you get.   I usually halve the recipe because it's just two of us but I always make the full recipe of gravy using cream of mushroom soup.  Tonight I only had one can of cream of mushroom soup so I used a can of French Onion soup with it and that was very, very good too.  In fact, I may start using one can of each from now on, it was that good.  You won't be sorry either way.  It's so good!  Update: You really should be out of the house while this is cooking because, just 1 hr. into the cooking time, the aroma makes you so hungry!

country:
None
text:
this was delicious as is! my son and husband ate it up! I only made a couple modifications so I could make it in my Instant Pot. first, I seared the patties right in the instant pot then stacked in a circle (2 layers of 4 patties). I added an extra 3/4 cup of broth to the gravy (I used water for the original portion) and also added some worshtershire sauce to make sure the gravy wasn't watered down. poured this on top of the patties and then pressure cooker for 15 minutes with a 10 minutes natural release. turned out AMAZING and the gravy was still thick and flavorful. my hubs said I can make it weekly if I'd like!

text:
This recipe is awesome as shown, but I made a few additions that just made it  even more FANTABULOUS!  

I added 1 whole egg to the ground beef mixture, it helps to hold the patties together better. 

I made my own mashed potatoes (skins on, sour cream added during whipping) and caramelized onions w/sliced mushrooms. 

I served the salisbury steak on top of a couple scoops of mashed potatoes, then topped it with the caramelized onions and mushrooms. 

I plan to add either some chives, green onions, or garlic to the mashed potatoes next time!

I definitely recommend this and it will become one of my "go to recipes" !

text:
When it comes to rating any recipe that I make from here, I make it exactly as directed.  I make no alterations hence my rating is purely about the recipe provided.   The aroma of the Salisbury steak cooking in my crockpot was truly a yummy tummy growling experience.   The flavor was very good.  The only reason I gave it 4 stars is that the salt content was too high.  I had left overs which I covered with the sauce and that made the steaks absorb even more of the salty flavor.  So based purely on the recipe as is, I would highly recommend it but I would suggest using low sodium cream of chicken soup.

text:
Great recipe!! I made a few changes...instead of water I used Beef Broth- and almost 3/4 of a can. I mixed it into the cream of mushroom soup mixture. The reason I added more than the recipe was to produce more gravy. The other change is I made was I used Beefy Onion soup mix instead of just onion, I've found doing that with other beef dishes, it really enhances the taste. I added salt, which it could have done without as it was salty enough on its own, it tasted perfect like that to me & my husband, but the kids said 'too salty'. Served it with mashed potatoes & corn & it was a huge hit!!

This turned out so much better than I expected.  Really tasty.  Two mistakes I made that will be of use to you I hope - 1) Use at least 85% ground beef.  I used 80% and got way to much grease in the sauce. 2) Make the patties fairly flat.  Mine swelled up to look like round balls in the cooking process.

text:
I thought the chicken soup was an odd choice, so I swapped it for mushroom soup. I could also see how it would be way too salty with given ingredients depending on your tastes - so for those who haven't made this yet, remember you can always add but not take away. I ended up with twice as much gravy as I really needed, but I think that might just be my husband and my preference. Otherwise, it was great! This is now my go-to salisbury steak recipe. 
Enjoyed last night with brown rice, steamed broccoli, and I had some portobello mushrooms in the fridge, so I threw them in at the end just to get coated with the gravy.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677177.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
It tasted good, but it just didn't taste like classic salisbury steak.
I did have to change a couple of things.
Had to use crushed up crackers b/c I didn't have breadcrumbs. I added in some Italian seasoning with it.
I also used beef stock instead of water to give it more flavor.
It was a little salty according to my husband, but I thought it was fine. Pair it with some underseasoned mashed potatoes or white rice and it should help reduce the saltiness if it bothers you.
I also cooked this for around 7 hours, just because I had a free moment to get all of it done and in to the pot.
I'll make this again, but will change it a little more to try out different flavors. Like using cream of mushroom, maybe adding in an onion and peppers too.

Minimum amount of ingredients with easy instructions. The steaks have a very good taste, but may be a little salty for some; in which case I would suggest a "low sodium" soup. Just one thing to note, there will be a lot of grease that you may want to spoon or siphon out prior to serving.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I read just about all of the reviews. I used one can of cream of mushroom because it was all I had. After pouring the cream of mushroom out I filled the can with water and added that to the gravy mix. I used 1 au jus packet and about half a cup of beef broth. I read that it was salty so I added an addition 1/4 cup water. I also added a tablespoon of  worcestershire as well.  I didn't use a crockpot because I didn't have time. I cook it on the stove for an hour on low heat. My family loved it. I love reading all of the reveiws to see the tips others give and how they made it their own. I serve it with sticky rice and crescent rolls.

text:
Not sure the 5 star works because I used cream of Mushroom soup.  But the result was so GOOD.  I also added  half onion and 1/2 cup of mushrooms that had to be used.  The 'burgers' were very good - had to use a cracked egg that I broke getting the mushrooms and onion out of frig so cut back to 1T milk and the cracked egg.  Next time I make this I will make the meat patties 'flatter' not so thick.  For me the gravy was too thick so I added more liquid (beef broth/water) - Served with mashed potatoes.  Very happy with the overall recipe - will use it again.  Really liked the flavors better with the left-overs. The last thing - didn't use the slow cooker used my small electric fry pan on lowest setting for 45 min.

text:
First time making this recipe. Overall it was easy to make and a delicious addition to my week night meals.  After reading the reviews regarding the recipe coming out to salty I decided to add about a 1/4 cup of brown sugar to help cut through some of the saltiness. This definitely helped and did not make it sweet. My husband loved it and did not think it was to salty. My mom, who eats very little salt still thought it was a little to salty.  When I make this again, I will use low sodium products to help offset the saltiness. Cook time in my crockpot was dead on and the meat was fork tender. Served it with mashed taters. So good.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677173.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I gave this recipe 5 stars even though I made changes based on personal likes and dislikes.   For the meat mixture I followed this recipe, as written with the exception of dredging the meat through flour.   I am working on cutting grains and didn't feel it was a necessary step.  I also replaced the onion soup mix for Beef flavor onion soup mix.  After the meat was done I sauteed an onion and a package of fresh baby portabellas (sliced).   For the gravy mix I used 1 jar of beef gravy and a packet of au jus gravy mix with 3/4 Cup water.   

This recipe was super easy and simply delicious.   I am sure it is equally delish as written, however I am not a fan of cream soups.  If you are looking for an easy meal that is full of flavor give this one a try, you won't be disappointed.

text:
I used 1/2 pkg of the onion soup mix.  I used 1 can of cream of mushroom instead of chicken.  Added 1/2 jar of gravy mix instead of aux jus and a couple of glugs of worcestershire sauce  and 1/2 cup of red wine.  We are big fans of mushroom and a lot of fresh sliced baby bella mushrooms.  I browned the hamburger and mushrooms in a pan and then added the sauce.  Braised them in the sauce for about an hour.  I served this over egg noodles; reminded me of the salsbury steak from my childhood. Great recipe.  My husband and I loved it and the leftovers two days later were even better.

text:
It's a winner for the Hubby, so I'll be making it again. I found it to be OK. To combat saltiness, I used reduced sodium mushroom soup; it must have worked, because neither of us found it too salty. I was concerned about the relatively 'short' cooking time (5 hrs), especially since this was my first ground-beef-patty crock pot meal. I got around it by making the patties the day before and freezing (this also made early morning assembly much easier). I took them out, coated in flour, and browned. They went into the crock pot still frozen inside. 9 hrs later, they were perfectly done and still shaped like beef patties.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
No leftovers! I used 3 pounds extra lean ground turkey, adding one egg. Also added 1/2 cup gluten free bread crumbs (made my own).  I used beefy onion soup and unsweetened almond milk in lieu of milk.
For gravy, I used 2 cans cream of mushroom soup and 1 pack au jus, adding 1 cup water
Started using almond flour but then decided to use regular flour since almond flour doesn't thicken like regular flour and the recipe wasn't going to be gluten free.
I also added sliced mushrooms about an hour before turing the crock pot off
Everyone loved it!

text:
We have a family camping tradition of eating canned meatballs with potatoes and vegetables, it is better than you think but I could not get over the poor nutritional content! I made this recipe and the kids said it tastes just like our tradition.  I make a double recipe (except the sauce), brown them all in the frying pan but then freeze half of the meatballs for another day.  Later I would defrost overnight, mix up the sauce in the morning and another meal will be ready by dinner. Delicious.  My kids request this often.

text:
This is my go to recipe that I make once a week!  I tweeked it just a bit:
I use ground turkey.

And, for the gravy - my family likes LOTS of gravy I use:

2 cans cream of mushroom soup
3 envelopes of turkey gravy mixed with 3 cups water

thats my tweek!

I think the secret to this recipe is dredging the patties in flour -  doing that just makes the patties so moist!

I mixed 1# ground beef with half a packet of onions soup mix, made in to 4 patties, seared in skillet, put in slow cooker, mixed 1 can of soup with 3/4 packet of au jus mix and some water and poured over steaks and cooked on high for about 3 hours. text:
Although I have been a browser for years this is my first review.  This is an easy fantastic meal that I cook 2 or 3 times a month.  There are only two of us but I make the entire recipe with 1 1/2 lbs of beef so we can have leftovers and a quick lunch.  Like others I do use cream of mushroom rather than cream of chicken and I also add a box of baby bellas. The extra gravy is great on toasted bread too.  If you have teenage boys or young men in your house do not expect the ratio of one serving to be enough for them.  When the grand kids are here they eat it up.

I made this last night for dinner. I put it together on my lunch hour. I read a lot of the reviews before hand, some said it was too salty and some greasy. I added half of the packet of onion soup mix and also chicken broth instead of water. I put on the crock pot and it cooked for about 4-5 hours. It was very salty even with half the packet of mix, so I added water. It turned out to be very greasy. Next time I make this I'll use a leaner meat, then it should be better!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a great recipe!  I have made it for years, but had not made it in over a year.  I have had others tell me it was too salty, so I have added another pound of meat (total 3 lbs) and kept the other ingredients the same.  I do however swap the cream of chicken soup for one can cream of celery and one can cream of mushroom.  I also love mushrooms, so I add at 2 packages of freshly slides Baby Bella mushrooms to the top of the crockpot.  Yesterday I made this and put the patties in the crockpot for about 30 min, as I was making the gravy and slicing mushrooms.  When I was ready to add gravy, I noticed a great deal of grease, even though I had drained on paper towels prior to placing them in the crockpot.  I took the patties out, drained the grease, and rebuilt the pyramid.  Smothered with gravy. And completely covered the top of crockpot with 24 oz. mushroom.  Cooked on high for 5 hours...Fabo!!  (Seeing all the grease at the bottom reminded me how the gravy seems oily in the past.  Definitely remember to cook in crockpot for 30 min alone, drain fat, then add gravy.  The gravy looked great in the crockpot with the mushrooms...no greasy spots.)

Display Name:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674164.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
My family loved my version which I got inspiration from this recipe. I totally worked with what I had and it was done with mashed potatoes and fresh salad  in 1hr. I mixed 1 lb. of 93% lean hamburger with two eggs, approx. 1/4 c. milk,  1-1 1/2 c. of smashed up dressing crumbs, pepper in my kitchen Aid mixer. I snuck in some leftover chopped asparagus from XMAS eve. Get the consistancy like you would for  hamberger patties or meatloaf. I formed them  into patties and coated with flower and pepper and fried in large deep skillet in conolla oil. I mixed together in sepparte bowl 1 large (the family size) can of cream of mushroom soup along with 1 packet of beef au-juce powder and about 3/4 c. of milk and 1/4 c. of water. This will be the gravy so get it to your likening. I then pourd it over patties. Turned it down to medium low and let it simmer while I cooked the potatoes with skins on. I added garlic and butter to the potatoes and again used the Kitchen aid-mixer to whip them up. Yummy  My version made 8 large 1/2 inch patties.

text:
Good flavor and texture but way too salty. I even used half the onion soup mix and made half of the condensed soup  lower sodium as suggested in the reviews. Next time I make it, I will modify the sodium even more  by using even less of the soup packet and use all lower sodium condensed soup. Also, in order to keep the onion flavor, I will add some caramelized onions to the gravy. Finally, I browned the steaks as instructed but instead of using a crockpot, I  baked mine in the oven at 350 until the meat thermometer read 165 F. They held together well and were firm yet moist.

text:
This recipe is so yummy and easy!  I actually used this recipe to make Shepherd's Pie. I just brown the meat instead of making pattys and use the same seasoning and gravy recipe. Then layer it with mashed potatoes and veggies and bake it... if you really want to lose your mind- make the Shepherd's Pie with the potatoes on bottom and biscuit on top! Call it a Shepherd's Pot Pie! So many calories  - but so so good!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
THIS WAS A BIG HIT AT MY DINNER PARTY LAST NIGHT! My husband was super dubious over the entire concept of Salisbury Steak. He watched as I prepared the patties and he kept saying, "how is this different than meatloaf or burger patties?" I told him to be patient. His tone changed once he took his first bite! I think the entire party of 8 gave a collaborative "nomnom" with the meal. 

I looked through the comments about the Au Jus being too salty, so I chickened out and used brown gravy packets.

I do have to say, the crockpot was FILLED with grease after they were cooked. I took the patties out and placed them in a casserole dish and put them in the oven for about 30 minutes to "dry out". I had to get as much of the grease out of the gravy as possible.  I ended up transferring the gravy to a skillet and with the magic of cornstarch, made a nice hearty gravy. OH and I also used Cream of Mushroom and sauteed mushrooms in the gravy.

I WILL DEFINITELY BE MAKING THIS AGAIN!!! 
-ps- i served this with the slow cooker mashed potatoes and cream cheese corn. dessert was a New York Cheesecake with Strawberry Sauce. all recipes found here.

This is delicious!  With that said, I did "tweek" it a bit.  I omit the onion soup mix and slice a large onion and add it on top of the gravy once all  in the crock pot.  I also use cream of mushroom soup to replace one can of the cream of chicken soup.  I like to add fresh mushrooms to it also! I like to mix in some dried thyme and worcestershire to the meat mixture.   My family loves this.  We have it with mashed potatoes and corn!

text:
I made this recipe exactly as written and it tasted great.  The sauce turns into a perfect gravy topping for mashed potatoes. 

A few things worth mentioning: 

1) The patties shrink. I would say make 6 patties to feed 6 people. 

2) This recipe has quite a bit of sodium. I'll use low sodium soup and maybe try cream of mushroom next time. 

Bottom line, this recipe (or a variation of)  will probably be a monthly staple in our home.

text:
This came out perfect! Next time I will double it because everyone wanted seconds and I like to make enough for leftovers for lunch the next day however this did feed my family of four that eats well (two teenage growing boys with a fast metabolism) This really wasn't salty as some people suggested but then again we like a little salt to our food and I know my mom never salts her food and she tasted it and thought it was a tad bit on the salty side. For those who think it's too salty I would suggest you putting a potato in it not to eat but to absorb some of that saltiness but again to me it was perfect! I feel as if I hit the jackpot with this recipe cuz my whole family loves it.
Review:

This was the best!  So when I was writing out my shopping list I somehow forgot the au jus mix.  Since I had already started mixing everything, I used 2 packs of sazon instead. I added a bit of browning sauce and was good to go.  Made a meal with mashed potatoes and green beans.

This was very tasty!  Great comfort food.  The leftovers were even better.  I did use cream of mushroom soup instead of chicken soup, and mine was was not salty at all.  I also recommend making the patties thinner 1/2" or less. Otherwise, they may still be pink inside after 5 hours.  I expected mine to shrink a lot but they didn't (possibly due to the low fat beef I use).

userID:
5266979
Display Name:
Kristina Trento
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
4

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2602955.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
OK let me start by saying I love when people post their changes!  I've never followed a recipe word for word in my life - I'm more of a "by instinct" cook anyway.  All recipes are just a starting point for me.  And I hardly ever use processed or instant mixes if I can help it.
With that, here are my changes:
I used 94% lean beef, and used only half a packet of onion soup mix, with panko instead of bread crumbs (no additives!) and a tablespoon worchestershire.  I cooked the patties with chopped onions, then drained on paper towels.  To the pan I added mushrooms, covered 2 min, 2 tbsp flour,  1 tbsp worchestershire, 1/4 c merlot and a whole box of beef broth, a chicken bouillon cube and 1 tsp salt + 1/2 tsp pepper. I reduced, then added 1/2 cup milk, premixed with a 1 tbsp flour to thicken. You might want to add salt and pepper to taste later, so you control your own saltiness. It also makes plenty of extra gravy!
I put the patties into the crockpot, poured the homemede sauce over the top, and let cook on low for 5 hours.  We served this with garlic mashed potatoes and cooked baby carrots.
It was a little legthier prep this way, but wow oh wow, was it amazing.  Hubs and kids (and picky eater friend) gobbled up every bite! Next time I will skip the crockpot altogether and just finish it in the oven while I make the potatoes and carrots.

text:
I made this but used 3 tablespoons of Mrs Dash Onion & Herb Medley , 2 tablespoons of dehydrated onion flakes and1 teaspoon of onion powder instead of the onion soup mix.  I also added 1 tablespoon of worcestershire sauce, 1 tablespoon of low sodium catsup and 2 ounces of water instead of the milk. After browning the patties I added mushroom soup mix (enough to make 4 servings) and 3 cups of water. Let it all simmer on top of the stove for 45 minutes. Stirred it 2-3 times only. Sauteed sliced and onions and mushrooms and threw them in at the end. YUM!

Salty. Gravy a little thick. I adjusted the servings to 4.  But, it was really good!
I just didn't put much spice in the mash potatoes & stacked 'Mashed Potatoes-Gravy-Patty-Gravy' like the picture. Eating together diluted the taste of salt as a balance.

I hated Salisbury Steak as a child so when I became an adult this dish was definitely out of the question but up pops this recipe, I felt like I was on Masterchef  a clean plate favorite... Of course I had to put a lil sas to it...I added a dash of garlic powder and substituted cream of onion soup (1) can and used dry beef and mushroom gravy and instead of cooking it in the slow cooker, I prepared it on top of the stove other then that I stuck to the original recipe

This is an amazing recipe! The recipe is very simple and the prep time is minimal which is what I needed.  My husband and son loved it! The taste is perfect.  The gravy is to die for! I will use this gravy for my roasts from here on out. It's that good. Make it!  You won't regret it!

text:
I made this dish for meal prep. It was delicious but I did make a few changes. As everyone stated that the dish came out salty I tried to avoid that. I used ground chuck as I am not a fan of lean meat.To the flour dredge I mixed in garlic and onion powder and cooked them with canola oil  (no reason honestly-it was the 1st one I picked up). I only used half of the au jus mix and instead of water I used unsalted beef broth for more flavor. I let them cook on high in my Crockpot for about an hour and the rest on low bc after a long day of grocery shopping and cooking I wanted to speed up the process. I made smashed garlic potatoes with yellow gold potatoes as the side and used a bit of the sauce from the Crockpot as gravy. VERY TASTY although I'd advise you not to eat this in public as you may fall into a sleep coma. I think next time that I try this recipe I will used one pound ground chuck and one pound sirloin for a WOW factor...

9960237
Display Name:
tmf

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2540014.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
First time I've reviewed a recipe here! I've been eye-balling this recipe for weeks and decided it had to be tried. Read all the reviews first, then checked the pantry. Dry au jus gravy mix - check! Cream of chicken or cream of mushroom - non to be found, BUT found a can of cream of chicken with mushroom (best of both worlds)! 

Since I was cooking for two I used 1 lb of lean ground beef. Left out the dry onion soup mix (can't stand the stuff and never buy it) but added ~1/4 cup finely diced Vidalia onion. Browned the beef patties, removed from the skillet and added the cream of chicken with mushroom soup, 1 cup water and the whole packet of au jus gravy; stirred until fully combined and put the beef patties back in the skillet.  Spooned the gravy over the patties, lowered the heat and covered with a lid. Left it to cook for 20 minutes, turned the patties over and cooked for 30 minutes more.  Homemade mashed potatoes and steamed baby carrots on the side.  Hunny told me after dinner "don't make this again - TONIGHT - but definitely keep this recipe"!

None
text:
I made this really close to the recipe. My only change was that I since I didn't have ground beef on hand (I know! shameful!)but I had lots of ground turkey - so I substituted it. Plus, I added a can of mushroom stems and pieces on top of the steaks before adding the gravy mixture. Other than that, I followed the recipe to the letter. My husband wolfed his down before I was barely three bites into mine! I was concerned about the sodium content, but apparently I was the only one. The turkey was good, but I think I would have preferred the ground beef version. I agree with other reviewer that next time (of which there will be many) I will be more creative and try to cut the sodium; use cream of mushroom soup instead; try making the recipe entirely on top of the stove or try even baking it for a bit if I haven't planned ahead. Regardless, we really liked it and my husband had the leftovers portioned into take-out containers for his lunches for the next couple of days before I was even finished with my dinner. High praise, indeed!

38

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614246.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
After reading um-teen reviews, I decided to follow other reviewers' suggestions and my own intuition and omit the processed items and make this slow cooker dish. I sautéed an onion instead of using the onion soup mix. I made a roux and used it with sautéed mushroom as the basis for the gravy. Salisbury steak is classically served with onion gravy, so I sliced an onion very thinly and sweated it before adding it to the mix for the slow cooker. The meat was tasty, I had decreased the bread crumbs per other reviewers and served it over Chef John's mashed potatoes. My rendition was 5 stars but I had so modified the recipe that I had to give the original just 3 stars. This is the reason that I read the reviews on Allrecipes site before cooking. Thanks for the original idea Tesslynn.
Review:
Rating:
4
dateLastModified:

text:
Wow! This is a fantastic recipe. I did use Cream of Mushroom (I didn't mean to alter the recipe... must have just seen "Cream of" and defaulted to mushroom since it is Salisbury Steak). 

Anyway, the CoM I used was low sodium, so the recipe wasn't too salty for me. I neglected to use the flour when I browned the patties, and cooked everything for about 4.5 hours. The meat was incredibly flavorful, tender... just fantastic. I ended up with so much gravy I put a bit aside to freeze and use later. 

Also added one yellow onion - perfect! 

Thank you SO MUCH, Tesslynn, for sharing! :)

text:
this rating is really for the meat, because I did the sauce differently.  We really liked this.  The meat turned out very tender and moist.  I put carrots, mushrooms and potatoes in the bottom under the meat to make it a meal and added frozen peas to the top for the last half hour.  Because we don't like creamy sauces or "cream of" soups I used one can beef broth, one can water and one package of gravy mix instead.  Turned out very well.  Was a lot of liquid and was not as thick or flavorful as it could have been, so next time I might omit the water.  Thought this might be helpful for anyone else who likes salisbury steak but not creamy gravy.

Display Name:

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/global/features/3054.gif
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I tend to like a lot of salt, and I thought this was too salty. That's why I only gave 4 stars. Other than that, this is definitely a 5 star meal!

I made a few changes based on what I had on hand. I used cube steak instead of ground beef and did not brown beforehand.
I mixed the onion mix and bread crumbs together; dredged the steaks; and tried to pyramid them in my slow cooker.
Then I mixed one can cream of chicken, one can cream of mushroom and the au jus together. I don't remember if I added the water or not (oops!). Poured everything over the steaks and cooked on low all day while we were at work.
House smelled AMAZING when we got home. Steaks were super tender and flavorful.

We ate without any sides, but there was plenty of gravy to have had some with mashed potatoes, rice or noodles. That might also have helped it seem less salty.

I will definitely try again. Maybe trying to find low sodium soups or mixes or adding a bit more water.
Review:

5

text:
Made this today and it was a hit with the family. I made some of the suggested modifications, replaced one of the vans of cream of chicken with cream of onion and used beef broth and a bit of Worcestershire instead of au jus. I also added cubed potatoes the last couple of hours of cooking time. There was more prep work involved than what I would normally do for a slow cooker meal. For that reason I wouldnt recommend it for a weeknight dinner if you're short on time.  Overall very food and super simple. Will make this one again.

I saw a lot say it was salty and by itself it was , however if you take some potatoes and boil them for 25 to 30 mins. Drain the potatoes, and then mash them up really good, and serve the steak over the potatoes and eat them mixes together, you wont need low sodium anything. If you dont add any seasonings to the potatoes it makes the soups perfect mixed in the potatoes. This was an absolute favorite, my picky eater even asked for it to be served up for her lunch the next day.

text:
Soooo good. Used ground sirloin. There is no need to use a slow cooker and wait 5 hours for dinner. This can easily be thrown together in electric skillet and be done in 30 minutes. I actually think it tastes better this way and you don't need to coat meat in flour if doing it with skillet. I set skillet to 350 and then turn it down after meats browned. Just brown meat on each side and then add everything else. I add a big can of chopped mushrooms and double the water to make more sauce. My 3 year old said it's his favorite :)

text:
This is a very good slow-cooker meal and it is very flexible for substitutions. I used one lb. of ground beef and one lb. of ground pork for the meat. Also sub'd half a cup of chopped onion instead of the dry onion soup to reduce the sodium content. For the gravy I used one can of cream of chicken and one can cream of mushroom along with the water and au jus packet. The gravy just calls for lots of mashed potatoes . Very good and easy!

city:
