country:
None
text:
This was the first time I made Salisbury steak in my house and this recipe was a big hit, even with my picky kids. I stayed very close to the original recipe, only adding a small can of mushroom and 1/4 cup diced onions to the mix.  Also I only used 1 1/2 lbs of lean ground beef in stead of two lbs., but kept the amount of bread crumbs, onion soup mix, and water the same.  The result was fabulous, lots of tasty gravy and 6 good sized beef patties.  I did not think it was overly salty, but I did use the reduced sodium and fat cream of chicken soup.  It was so good served over homemade mashed potatoes with a side of peas and 7 up biscuits.  I will definitely be adding this recipe to the rotation.

text:
Winner winner beefy dinner! I did find this on the salty side but I'm sure there are ways to cut this down (lower sodium soups, use something else other than the onion soup mix in the meat, etc.) if you are watching your salt intake, but my family said DELICIOUS! The only change I made was to use one can of cream of chicken and one can of cream of mushroom as I only had one can of the cream of chicken. Great this way, so I think I will make it this way from now on! Very easy...get the meat and sauce in the crock pot, set your time and temperature, then walk away until dinner time!

country:
None
text:
I made this dish for my family and they absolutely loved it! Instead of 2 cans of cream of chicken soup, I used 1 can of cream of chicken and 1 can cream of mushroom. I added 1 envelope Lipton onion soup as well as 1 envelope Lipton onion mushroom soup mix to the ground beef mixture and about a tablespoon extra breadcrumbs. I went a bit further and chopped up 2 medium onions and added 20 ounces of fresh sliced portobello mushrooms. Last but not least, I double dredged the patties before searing off and added a full cup of water. The gravy turned out just lovely and the patties were very moist and flavorful! A definite keeper!

text:
This was very good!  Even my pickiest eater liked it, and everyone asked me to make it again.  If you have one of the new slow cookers (the ones that run hot), you probably don't need 5 hours in the slow cooker.  Mine were done in about 3 hours.  It also makes a huge batch - cutting in in half would have fed my family of 5.  

The only reason I'm taking a star off this recipe is that it's very salty.  I made some adjustments after reading the review, but it was still pretty salty.  Next time, I'll probably use low sodium soups, and low sodium beef broth in place of the au jus mix.

region:

country:
None
text:
My husband loved this! The plan was to cook exactly by the recipe but due to time and ingredient availability I ended up changing it a bit. As per other reviews, I used cr. of mushroom instead of cr. of chicken because that's what I had on hand. I also could not find the au jus mix (I may not have known where to look) so I used brown gravy mix exactly as it said to use the au jus mix. All other ingredients stayed the same. I made this for 4 instead of 8 and due to forgetting to put it in the crock pot, I ended up cooking it in a skillet. Things just don't always go as planned. It tasted great and was easy enough to make. I'm making it again tonight and I think the only thing I will change is crunching up the onion soup mix so it's a bit finer. I wasn't a fan of crunching into the dried onion bits in my meat. The flavor was good, I just didn't like the texture. Loved how tender it turned out and both my 2 year old and husband ate every bit. Definitely recommend trying this recipe. (even if I didn't follow it exactly)

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
i gave this 5 stars, but i changed it quite a bit.  i was only cooking for two (one being a toddler), so reduced amts quite a bit.  i was also concerned about prev reviews saying it was too salty.  I didn't have enough time for the slow cooker, so excited about a prev reviewer's comment that an electric skillet worked, i went with that idea.  here's what i did:  used 1/2 lb gr turkey & did step 1.  then, right into the pan the meat was in, i added thin chunks red potato, carrot, celery.  i let that cook a bit.  added maybe a cup of crm of mushroom soup, 1/4 cup water, and about a tsp of au jus base.  i simmered that for awhile till the veggies were close to done, added some canned peas and froz corn  (though i steamed the corn in the microwave first).  let it cook for a bit.  i served with homemade red skinned mashed potatoes.  absolutely divine!  not salty at all.. sorry i didn't list how much of everything i used, that's what kind of cook i am: i frequently have to reduce amts, so i just add as much/little as it needs.  you could do whatever you wanted with this!

text:
This is an awesome recipe for someone who is looking for a hearty meal that is fast and easy! It has become a family favorite for sure! As some other reviewers mentioned, it might be a bit salty for some people's liking, but I served it with rice and it really cut back how salty it tasted. 

I made  a few minor modifications that I think really help to make this recipe awesome: 
- I used bisquick instead of flower to coat the burgers.
-Instead of 2 cans of cream of chicken I did one can of the cream of chicken and 1 can of cream of mushroom soup. 
- Added sliced mushrooms, 1/2 cup of water and 1/2 of a large onion cut into slivers into the gravy mixture. 

With these few modifications, it comes out perfectly to my likely for hamburger steak! Hope you all enjoy!

text:
my husband loved the flavor here!  next time i will be making the following changes: 1) 1 lb. hamburger + 1 med. onion + 1/4 cup bread crumbs + 1/4 cup flour mixed together and browned.  2) To save on some fat and salt, i will be omitting the onion soup mix and vegetable oil.  3) the gravy will be unchanged, as we all loved it: 1 package fresh mushrooms browned in hamburger drippings, 2 cans condensed cream of chicken, 1 oz. dry au jus mix, and 3/4 cup water.  4)  the patties were good but an unneccessary step, so to save time i won't be pattying.  then after thoroughly browning the hamburger and putting the gravy together, the slowcooker is unneccessary.  Simply pour over potatoes and enjoy!

text:
This was an easy, delicious dinner.  I actually made it slightly different because I just didn't feel like preparing it in the morning for the slow cooker.  I used my pressure cooker!  I followed the recipe up until it was time to add the soup and au jus.  I layered them in a pyramid in the pressure cooker, mixed 2 cans of cream of mushroom and 1 cup of beef broth together, and poured it over the beef patties.  Set the pressure cooker to high and cooked for 10 mintues, followed by a quick release.  Served over egg noodles with the sauce.  Kids and husband ate it up.  Thanks for a great recipe!

text:
This was great!  Did a few changes.  Cooked in my electric skillet instead of the crock pot.  I used ground turkey;added 2 eggs to make sure the paddies would hold together; used an off-brand onion soup mix (lower sodium) than Lipton's brand.  I also used golden mushroom soup (low sodium) and Heinz brown mushroom gravy.  After browning the paddies, I sauteed a sweet onion in drippings.  Simmered all in the electric skillet for 45 min. to an hour.  It dish was a huge hit!  Served with garlic roasted potatoes, french style green beans and corn bread muffins.

I too had a problem with this meal being way too salty, but that might be because I had to sub 1 can of golden mushroom soup (I've never used it before so I don't know if it's generally salty).  I don't normally mind some salt but this was too much for even me.  I did like the meat patties though, those came out like I would expect of Salisbury Steak, so I will try again and not stray from the original recipe and then re-rate if I get different results.  I also tried the 1/4 of red wine, didn't care for it, so will leave that out next time too (didn't factor that into my rating).  Oh, I tried the trick with the peeled, quartered potato to absorb some of the saltiness, it worked... at least it wasn't AS salty after it sat in there a while.

text:
I had to add more bread crumbs and milk to make the patties what they needed to be. This could of had something to do with using 70/30 ground beef instead of a leaner one, but hey I'm an el-cheapo. I also omitted the flour and vegetable oil really didn't see a need for it with the type of meat I used. I cooked my patties in the pan a bit longer since they have a fair amount of fat in them. I wasn't sure about the gravy but after 4 hours of cooking with the patties it was quite pleasant. We enjoyed it served over rice. All in all I tweaked it a bit for what I had on hand and will use this method again. Thx for the recipe!!

text:
Hmmm. This was good, just not great (or what I am looking for in a salisbury steak recipe). It is sure easy to prepare though.... I think I like salisbury steak by Kelly Berenger a little better and will stick with that recipe when the craving calls. I like the fact that this recipe takes advantage of the slow cooker (I LOVE using mine!). Kelly's recipe uses the stovetop, but I like her gravy recipe better (it is tangy - which I prefer over savory). Perhaps I could combine the two? Instead of using cream of chicken soup/au jus mix, I could prepare the gravy from Kelly's recipe, but make the patties as directed here and cook in the sc??? Overall, good, just not "tickle my taste buds good." Served with mashed potatoes, peas, crescent rolls and the rest of the gravy to drizzle over the meat and potatoes (yum-o). One note: be sure to use LEAN beef! I used ground chuck (I bought a 5 lb. tube of it b/c it was on sale - being jobless, I am pinching pennies right now...). I had to use my turkey baster to remove a LOT of grease, but luckily it was easy to do since the oil separated and rose to the top. It was time consuming though and not recommended if you can afford the leaner stuff! Thanks for sharing, TESSLYNN :)

I thought this was a great 'base' recipe- I used it as a guide- because I wanted salisbury steak- but had what I had in the kitchen- lol.  I used ground turkey- and a can of french onion soup instead of the packet (I didn't have the packet)- and extra bread crumbs to absorb the extra soup- mixed that all together for the patties- and added some leftover fresh mushrooms that neeeded to be used.  Then I put them in the slow cooker- and mixed a can of mushroom soup with a jar of beef gravy and poured it over the top and went away.  I served this over mashed potatoes and it was DELICIOUS!  Fabulous comfort food!!!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
An excellent dish!  I read all the reviews and tweaked this one to perfection.  You must use the leanest ground beef available.  To decrease the salty flavor I first sprayed my roaster/crockpot with PAM then covered the bottom with thin potatoe slices.  I used lower sodium cream of mushroom 1 can and cream of chicken 1 can in the sauce mixture.  When blending the ground beef with the dry ingredients you need to use your hands and "over blend" until the mixture no longer looks like ground beef but beef "paste".  The rest of the recipe was as written and it could not have been more delicious.  This one is definitely going into my rotation.  Thank you so much for this post.

text:
I have cooked this several times, it's one of my favorites.  The first time I did find the gravy to be a bit salty, so the subsequent times I made it I cut the au jus powder I added in half.  I don't think the soups are making the recipe too salty, I think the au jus packet is the culpret.  This recipe tastes good to me no matter what soup I use, currently it's cooking with one can of cream of mushroom and one cream of chicken.  My whole family loves this recipe, even my picky kids.  Great comfort food!  I do add a bunch of baby carrots to the bottom of my crock to add a vegetable to my meal.  Turns out great!

text:
Excellent! I made very few changes. I used 2 can cream of mushroom soup instead of chicken soup, added fresh mushrooms and a splash of red wine. Also, for those complaining about the salt, don't use Lipton Onion Soup Mix (for this or any other recipe). It is way too salty. Campbells or the store brand onion soups are much less salty and just as good.

text:
I gave this 4 stars because it was salty. I read the reviews so I was tasting as I went along. I added the Au Jus mix and 1 can of cream of mushroom because it sounded better. I let it cook for about 2 hours and tasted the gravy and found it to be VERY salty. So I added some basic beef stock and garlic powder and let it cook. I tasted it again and found it to be lacking a little something so I added some Kitchen Boquet, It then tasted more like I wanted. After it was all said and done I found the meat to be tender and juicy and the gravy was good served with mashed potatoes.

text:
I loved this recipe. I didnt feel like waiting on it in the slowcooker, so I browned the meat on both side in the skillet,then I placed it on a cookie sheet in the oven on 375 for 20 min.  In the skillet where I browned my meat, I added the can cream and chicken, and broth (instead of packet dry au jus mix & water) and simmered until meat was cooked.  Then I placed the meat back in the skillet to get it covered in the gravy.  I served with green beans and rotini noodles.  Only thing I suggest is doubling the sauce.  Awesome recipe.

text:
This receipe was delicious.  I had to improvise a little since I did not have all the ingredients and really wanted to make it.  Instead of the onion soup mix, I used minced onion and put it in the food processor with seasoned bread cubes (did not have seasoned bread crumbs)and ground it up real fine like bread crumbs.  I also used a package of brown gravey mix...did not have the au jus mix.  I used cream of mushroom soup instead of the cream of chicken and a can of chicken broth...some in the meatball mixture and some in the "gravy" mixture.  Used large fresh mushrooms in between the layers of the patties so the patties would be separated. It turned out wonderful!  Thanks for a great recipe.

This is very good and "a keeper" according to my husband who loves comfort food.  I cut the recipe in half as I was cooking for two, I browned the patties in a cast iron deep sided skillet, and left them there to simmer in the gravy on the stovetop while I prepared mashed potatoes to serve w/ the steaks.  It worked perfectly on the stovetop.  The recipe is a little on the salty side for me, but my husband thought it was fine.  I will be making this again with low sodium ingredients.

Also, this is a bit salty, so I recommend using at least one can of reduced sodium soup.  I will definitely me making this again.  It's a down home cooking/comfort food.

text:
Very nice taste and texture.  I did make some adjustmenst based on the # of people I was cooking for (2 adults and 1 small child).  I only did 1# of hamburger but added the entire envelope of soup mix but halved the rest of the steak ingredients.  I didn't have cream of chicken on hand so used cream of mushroom soup.  I still added the entire envelope of au jus mix.  I did however, throw in a diced potato to absorb the extra saltiness and also sliced some portabellas and added to the sauce in addition to also adding some minced dried onion.  Quite tasty but my version was still a little salty-will make as stated next time.

Me and my family LOVE this recipe!!

I made this last week and my husband ohh and ahhed over it.  I thought it was ok (but I am not a huge fan of ground meat) and it made a huge amount for the two of us.  I don't have a crock pot so I just cooked it on 200 for a few hours in a pot.  I served with mashed potatoes and the gravy was very good.

text:
I love the convenience of this ~ and the meat was nice and tender. I used one can of low sodium cream of chicken soup and one can of regular cream of chicken and mushroom because that is all I had. It was pretty salty, but tolerable.  I served it with hot bread, mashed potatoes, and mixed vegetables. I don't know if I'll fix it again or not... only one kid out of three liked it. I liked it but husband hated it. He's so picky though ~ he doesn't count!! :-)

text:
This recipe was awesome! I have some very picky children who loved this. I added the extra water like others had suggested, however the next time I make it I will not. I did not find it too salty(and I do not like meals salty!). I would prefer to have the gravy a little thicker so I think I would stay with the recommended amount of water that the recipe calls for.
